qas.question: Which three names did MCA use for LaserDisc technology during its development?

answers.text: Optical Videodisc System, "Reflective Optical Videodisc" or "Laser Optical Videodisc"

qas.question: To what did MCA change the name to in 1969?
When did MCA remove the hyphen from the name Disco-Vision?
Which company owned the rights to the world's largest collection of films during the 1970s?
Consumer sales of MCA films began in 1978 with what movie?

context: During its development, MCA, which co-owned the technology, referred to it as the <a0_0>Optical Videodisc System, "Reflective Optical Videodisc" or "Laser Optical Videodisc"<a0_0/>, depending on the document; changing the name once in 1969 to <a1_0>Disco-Vision<a1_0/> and then again in <a2_0>1978<a2_0/> to DiscoVision (without the hyphen), which became the official spelling. Technical documents and brochures produced by MCA Disco-Vision during the early and mid-'70s also used the term "Disco-Vision Records" to refer to the pressed discs. <a3_0>MCA<a3_0/> owned the rights to the largest catalog of films in the world during this time, and they manufactured and distributed the DiscoVision releases of those films under the "MCA DiscoVision" software and manufacturing label; consumer sale of those titles began on December 15, 1978, with the aforementioned <a4_0>Jaws<a4_0/>.
